docs.lead_paragraph: Many immigrants come to the United States for the good life. But a new study suggests that living well can carry a cost. Over the years, researchers report, immigrants tend to become just as obese as born-and-bred Americans -- even if they are from countries where obesity is less common.
docs.snippet: Many immigrants come to the United States for the good life. But a new study suggests that living well can carry a cost.

headline.kicker: The Great Divide | A Missing Generation
headline.main: Rural Exodus for Work Fractures Chinese Family

docs.abstract: Article in series The Great Divide, examining widening gap between China's rural poor and urban rich, focuses on plight of rural peasants who are forced to seek work far from home, leaving their children behind in care of relatives; millions of rural children are growing up without one or both parents; money sent home by migrant workers has become essential for jobless rural China, but even that is no longer enough; migrant wages have stagnated, education and health costs are rising, and rural society safety net has collapsed; income divide is widening rapidly in China, at expense of rural poor; studies show medical costs are leading reason people fall into poverty in China; many city residents still have some health benefits, but peasants now fall under pay-for-service system; sickness can mean bankruptcy; problems in village of Shuanghu discussed; photos; map (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: Yang Shan is in fourth grade and spends a few hours every day practicing her Chinese characters. Her script is neat and precise, and one day, instead of drills, she wrote letters to her parents and put them in the mail. ''How is your health?'' she asked. Shan, who is 10, then added a more pointed question: ''What is happening with our family?''
docs.snippet: For millions of families in the Chinese countryside, the only way to survive as a family is not to live as one.

headline.main: The Nation; Exchanging Cigarettes For Bagels

docs.abstract: Obesity is considered major public health problem, but number of scientists are coming to see it as comparative blessing, given alternative; they believe that America may have traded smoking--truly lethal habit--for lesser deadliness of eating too much; photo (M)/
docs.lead_paragraph: OBESITY is considered a major public health problem today, but a number of scientists are coming to see it as a comparative blessing, given the alternative. These public heath experts believe, in effect, that America may have traded smoking -- a truly lethal habit -- for the lesser deadliness of eating too much. The story of this trade-off can be seen in the data. From 1973 until 1983, Americans were actually growing thinner. During that period, the average weight of middle-aged men fell about two pounds, while that of middle-aged women fell nearly three pounds.
docs.snippet: Some public heath experts believe that America may have traded smoking - a truly lethal habit - for the lesser deadliness of eating too much.
